description:
Linanthus parryae, commonly known as Parry's linanthus, is a species of annual flowering plant in the family Polemoniaceae. It is native to the western United States, primarily found in the Mojave and Sonoran deserts.

Linanthus parryae is a small, delicate plant that typically grows to a height of 2-10 cm. The leaves are narrow and linear, often forming a basal rosette. The flowers are small, measuring around 1-2 cm in diameter, and come in various shades of white, pink, or purple. The corolla (the petals collectively) is funnelform or salverform, with five lobes.

The plant reproduces through self-pollination or cross-pollination by small insects, such as bees and butterflies. It is adapted to the harsh desert environment, with its small size and ability to quickly complete its life cycle before the onset of the dry season.

Linanthus parryae is an important component of the desert ecosystem, providing nectar and pollen resources for various pollinators. It is also of interest to botanists and ecologists for its adaptations to the challenging desert conditions and its role in the broader plant community.
